page.title: 01Dogdyke Lincolnshire
page.content: Dogdyke (Dock-dyke) was once the site of a ferry, the inn which stands there today still bears it's name, "the packet". Water plays an enormous part in this landscape, there are natural waterways, (Rivers Witham and Bain), man-made lakes and dykes for land drainage, a necessary feature of modern farming the major land use in this block. RAF Coningsbury airfield features greatly, its role is air defence, twenty-four bomb proof shelters dominate the skyline. A watersports centre has grown up on exhausted gravel workings. The block also supports an aviation museum and a preserved pumping station with origional beam engine. The river Witham completely splits the block, to join Dogdyke now requires a drive of some six miles. The Parish of Dogdyke supports two hamlets with
